Name: Statuette of a sparrow hawk
Description: The sparrow hawk, also known as the Akhom-falcon, is perched on a convex curved base painted yellow. The body has no limbs, and the facial markings are those of a falcon. The face has a white background, the head is blue. Back and wings are yellow for the upper third, the body and tail are red. On the chest and back a narrow green-white ornate collar is painted. The oblong green menat reaches the middle of the back.Carved birds like this one were part of the tomb equipment in the Late Period. They were placed on mummiform coffins, canopic chests, funerary stelae and on the bases of Ptah-Sokar-Osiris statues, and protected the deceased with their magic.
